climbs.name: Willard
climbs.fa: Dave Houser, Darryl Nakahira, Doug Zeisner, Dave Vaught, Todd Gordon, Paul Quinn and Ian Carter, November 1980

content.description:
This is a fun, well bolted (for Joshua Tree) face climb up friction face and scoops; a nice moderate far away from the usual crowds.

Note: there's a midway anchor but it can easily be done in one pitch.
content.location:
Just right of the obvious crack of

Last Angry Arab

.

content.description:
This route is on the far right side of the west face of Nomad Dome and ascends face and cracks to an obvious roof.  Pass the roof and continue up on large loose flakes to a two bolt anchor/rappel.

Moderate with that Woodward sting.
content.protection:
Protection is sparse but adequate.  A single set of cams to 2", set of stoppers and maybe a couple double length slings to tie off the loose flakes.  Bolt anchor/rappel 50 meters double ropes recommended for rappel.

It would be a good idea to have your partner wear a helmet and sunglasses with the loose flakes you will be sending down.

climbs.name: Last Angry Arab
climbs.fa: John Wolfe, Rob Stahl and Bob Dominick, 1972

content.description: This fun climb tackles the obvious crack system splitting the west face. Expect fun climbing with great views of the Astro Domes and the surrounding area from the summit.
content.location: Center of Nomad Dome's west face.

climbs.name: Final Furious Farsi
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, Bob Anderberg, Bill Thomas and Thom Scheuer, April 1985

content.description:
A fun and well-protected face climb to the right of Willard that angles up and left to join that route at it's anchors. Rap off from the anchors of Willard or continue up and top out via Willard.

Due to the circuitous nature of this route slings instead of quickdraws may be helpful on some of the bolts.

climbs.name: Ben
climbs.fa: Dave Houser, Darryl Nakahira, Doug Ziesner, Todd Gordon & Ian Carter, November 1980

content.description: The furthest left route on the west face, this climbs past a small roof (crux) down low to easier face moves above. The anchor is below the top of the rock, but one can easily climb past to the top of the rock.
